intro: Zaluzianskia berteroi, commonly known as the Bitterleaf morning glory, is a herbaceous perennial plant native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the Convolvulaceae family and is characterized by its trumpet-shaped, showy flowers that range from white to pink. The plant has heart-shaped leaves with a slightly hairy texture and produces edible seeds, though the leaves and stems are generally considered toxic. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in wetlands or along streambanks.
